Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Microbiome Analysis of Household Biofilm Specimens in Flint, Michigan

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1639066
Kilgore

In April 2014, the city of Flint switched its water supply from Detroit's system (Lake Huron) to the Flint River as a cost-saving measure. The increased corrosiveness resulted in the release of heavy metals (e.g., lead and iron) into the water supply. This RAPID grant addresses a critical gap in our knowledge and offers a timely, yet unique opportunity to advance our fundamental understanding of bacterial communities that make up biofilms in the Flint potable water distribution systems.

Biofilm and amoebic hosts are an important habitat for pathogens and protect them from disinfectants such as chlorine. Individuals may be exposed to aerosolized Legionella spp., Mycobacterium spp., and Pseudomonas spp in contaminated water from shower heads, shower plumbing, and water heaters. Despite recognition that contaminated water exposure is an important risk factor for Legionellosis, there is currently limited information on bacterial populations that coexist with Legionella spp. within biofilm microbiomes. In this project, the PIs proposed research will characterize bacterial biofilm communities and their distribution within potable water distribution systems supplying Flint households. Using metagenomic analysis targeting 16S rDNA, the PIs hypothesize that biofilm bacterial populations may vary by household distance from water treatment sites as well as by physico-chemical characteristics of water collected concurrent with biofilm sampling. Currently, household sampling of potable water and biofilm swabs from household shower pipes and humidifiers are being analyzed using standard culture and molecular methods for the presence of Legionella spp. The aim of this study is to compare microbiome found in biofilm specimens with and without Legionella spp. The study will utilize quantitative PCR and DNA sequencing methods to identify bacterial pathogens biofilm microbiomes. The proposed project will provide novel characterization of bacterial species in biofilm microbiomes of Flint households. These data will be used to compare potable water chlorine levels among specimens with and without Legionella spp. Results from microbiome analysis will used to guide future environmental sampling and surveillance for Legionella and other bacterial pathogens. Moreover, available Legionella spp. isolated from case-patients in the epidemic of 2015 will be genetically compared with those identified among biofilm specimens in Flint households. The results of this work will help guide the development of important intervention strategies to reduce OPPP exposure and protect susceptible individuals from these potential pathogens.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Humans come into contact with a wide variety of small organisms every day.  In fact, the human body itself has an invisible population of small organisms called bacteria. These bacteria live throughout the body (both inside and out).  In the same way that we find organisms living on us and in us, we know that a wide variety of organisms also live in our environment. These organisms include bacteria, viruses, parasites, fungi, and more. Scientific research on how these organisms affect human health is now emerging.  Such research tells us that some organisms may play an important role in determining our overall health and our risk for certain diseases. Of the organisms that humans encounter every day, some can live on the surface of our body or in our gut (gastrointestinal tract). Some of these bacteria may be found in our nose, throat or even our airways and lungs. Many of these bacteria live and grow on us without causing us harm. Other bacteria that we contact may, at times, cause illness or disease. A good example of this type of illness in pneumonia.  We know, for example that, pathogenic Gram-negative bacteria such as Klebsiella pneumoniae) can survive and grow in the environment (including water systems).  In some cases, bacteria in water systems have been known to result in exposures within institutional settings such as hospitals or long-term care facilities. In this project, we collected 34 shower pipe samples from households in Flint, Michigan. Samples were collected from the slimy film coats the inside of pipes, called a biofilm, leading to the showerhead. Genetic material, DNA, for the bacteria present on the inside of the pipe surface was extracted from these biofilm samples. DNA from each sample was extracted in the Henry Ford Health System Infectious Disease Laboratory using standard methods. Metagenomics sequencing studies were performed at the Applied Genomic Technology Center at Wayne State University. The amplification and sequencing of the 16S ribosomal RNA gene was performed the Illumina Demonstrated 16S Protocol. Using this protocol, the V3 and V4 region of the 16S RNA gene were amplified using the S-D-Bact-0341-b-S-17/S-D-Bact-0785-a-A-21, making the amplicon size 464 base pairs.  The 16s Metagenomics (https://basespace.illumina.com/apps/593593/16S-Metagenomics?preferredversion) application in Illumina?s BaseSpace (https://basespace.illumina.com) bioinformatics platform will be used for preliminary classification of bacteria taxonomies within the samples. Our analysis showed that DNA from a variety of organisms was present in household (also called premise) plumbing across Flint, Michigan following changes in the water supply in 2016. Results show that many of the bacteria found are also commonly found in the environment, including soil. The presence of DNA present in bacteria found included Legionella pneumophila, Acinetobacter baumannii, Mycobacterium ulcerans, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Haemophilus influenza, Stenotrophomonas maltophila, Haemophilus influenza. The presence of DNA from these different organisms inside water pipes suggests that these bacteria were living within some Flint premise plumbing, surviving in the biofilm. However, finding DNA from different bacteria does not tell us for sure if these bacteria are alive.  For this, we need to conduct additional research that collects biofilm samples from a larger number of household plumbing systems. Extending this research across the U.S. to understand those bacteria we may be exposed to in households will provide important additional information on potential risks to human health that can be reduced with interventions that reduce the growth of potential pathogens in our environment. Information from this study has provided new insights into bacterial populations (including potentially pathogenic bacteria) to which residents of Flint and other populated areas of the U.S. may be exposed to in the course of their daily lives. This study helps lay the foundation for more in-depth analysis of microbial communities to better understanding bacterial networks present in potable water distribution systems (WDS) and hospital WDS systems and how such networks influence coupled molecular processes in biofilm communities. Such results may help identify future opportunities for improving WDS engineering as well as treatment of potable water across system that use various forms of plumbing that may include lead, cast iron or PVC piping.
